history.content: I suggest 161+126+104 in fall and 189+127+135 in spring. 189+126+182 is too much for most people. 189 is helpful for 182, and if you don't take 189 before 182, you'd better take 126+127 before. 135 requires probability knowledge deeper than 70. 127+189 concurrently is a good combo. I asked a TA and the TA said people should take 126 before 189.

children.subject: I think the question of of timing is hard to answer, because admissions departments are so ambiguous, but if it eases your worries a little, when I applied to grad school a few months ago they had a space to list courses you were currently taking or plan to take, and you can list 182 there to show its presence on your "transcript" . They also sometimes have a small paragraph for you to explain things, were you can also note your plan to take 182 in senior spring.

Oh ok. I wasn't really worried, but I was just curious because someone told me to take 182 but it wasn't originally in my plan and I was only wondering if it's even important (I'm taking 189 spring 2021 anyway), or like you said worth mentioning in additional information box of app. I was only wondering if grad schools liked it better if someone took 182. I saw that self studying CS231n from Stanford is pretty good too, though.

I think that question is hard to answer because there is no perfect formula for grad school admissions. If you're interested in ML, depending on the school an extra course on nn might be helpful, but you should first focus on 189 and getting a good grad in there, and also determining whether you like nn enough to devote an entire semester to it
If you want to showcase an interest in ML, a general ML class like 189 is probably a better bet than a more specific class like 182, especially given that you already have nn research under your belt

Do you think it is important for me to have taken 182 by junior year? Judging from your response it seems like it isn't as important to have it finished by junior spring for masters/grad school programs. Also sourced @12092 @11439, it seems to not be as big deal/important to rush? I wish 182 was just offered in fall..

history.content:
I'm taking CS161, EE127, Math 104 this fall semester. Initially I was going to take CS189, EE126, Stat 135 next spring but now I'm realizing I would really want to take CS182 spring because I'm a junior and I want to get ready to apply to masters and want to show a focus in ML (I currently do neural network related research so 182 would be pretty useful). I think CS182 is only offered in the spring (correct me if I'm wrong) though which is why I'm kind of confused/unsettled about my schedule.

I'm pretty stable with my existing fall semester schedule and with research I think the workload is good. I really want to take EE126 spring semester, but I think that CS189 EE126 CS182 can be too heavy.. is there a better way to adjust my fa/spring semester schedule? Or can someone comment on the workload of 182 specifically because this is a new change. I originally liked the spring 2021 plan until I remembered CS182
history.subject: Spring 2021 Schedule
